subject: Law
title: The Right to Privacy
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Right to Privacy usable.

hook.text: The word 'privacy' never appears in the Constitution. Yet the Supreme Court found it thereâ€”hidden between the lines.

buildup.text: Griswold v. Connecticut (1965) found a right to privacy in the 'penumbras' of the Bill of Rights.

discovery.text: Privacy underpinned Roe v. Wade (abortion), Lawrence v. Texas (intimacy), and other landmark personal liberty cases.

twist.text: Dobbs (2022) rejected the privacy foundation for abortion, saying it wasn't deeply rooted in American history.

climax.text: Digital privacy adds new dimensions: how far does privacy reach when your phone tracks your every move?

punchline.text: Privacy is implied, not written. That makes it powerfulâ€”and vulnerable.

quiz.question: Where did the Supreme Court find the right to privacy?
